text: the stock markets in the currency
markets around the world have been in
turmoil for the last day and in some
ways the turmoil overseas is even more
dramatic than in the united states the
british pound fell more in a single
training session today than at any time
since 1971 and so the question for
policymakers today is what can the
United States and other countries do to
stem this investor panic and they do
have some options the International
Monetary Fund is discussing a way to
broaden its loan program to lend dollars
to countries that are economically in
relatively good shape but are facing
liquidity crunches as a result of all
their foreign capital being pulled out
of their markets separately there are
also rumors circulating in the market
today that the group of seven leading
industrialized countries may intervene
in a coordinated way in the currency
markets in a way that would take some of
the pressure off emerging market
currencies which have been plummeting in
recent days when these currencies
plummet it puts countries like Brazil
South Africa Turkey in a very difficult
situation because much of their debt
whether it's held by corporations or
even by the government is denominated in
u.s. dollars so when their currencies
swoon they suddenly can't pay off their
debts and they have the danger of
actually going into default
